transcripts.text: Hey Reluctant Preppers!

I'm your host, Donegan Kaiser.
And I'm Melody Kaiser.

And we're here to talk about a distressing situation that we made it through and survived and to offer some helpful tips that'll help you get through that.  And that's about the risks of colonoscopies and how you can get some serious side effects and how we found some natural treatments that were able to pull us out of that.  So the story starts, as many of ours tend to, with Lyme disease, which I contracted in the woods from a tick and brought home and was generous enough to pass on to my wife, which they don't tell you you can, but you can.  And so because we're both chronic Lyme survivors, this is something we've been battling for a long time.  We had over a year of antibiotic therapy, which really weakened our immune systems because your gut and your intestines and the natural flora that exists in your intestines is actually the place that your body can contact the outside world more than even outside of you is, more of the outside of you is inside of you than you see from the outside.  And so both of us have noticed that our immune systems in general and our ability to resist catching things that we get exposed to is reduced since then.  So we have to be very watchful and cautious about exposure.  Well, it turned out that...

Well, I think one of the other things just to say the antibiotics did was not only lower our immune system, but also, and then we said it in another video, but gut candida, which also I think, I'm not sure about that, but lowers your immunity too, because your body's fighting off many different things.  And so anyway, just to add that.

And in one of the treatments that we tried for our Lyme was a particular herbal protocol.  This happened to be one called VitalPlan.  And I think that particularly for me, I was intolerant of that and would get pretty bad stomach aches and some nausea.  It turned out I started having low blood iron, which has happened in the past, and it can with Lyme.  But this was like worse than usual, like more rapidly, like instead of a year between needing iron infusions or two or four years, it was like two months and that kind of thing.

I think it took you a little longer time.  I think I had the intuitive thing to say, hey, you know, the vital plan doesn't seem to be working for you.  I was okay with it, but you started getting stomach aches and you weren't relating it to that.  I really was, yeah.  And I said, I think we really need to get off that.  But you stayed on it longer than I think you should have.

I was stuck on it as a hope that it would simplify our regimen because our regimen of so many different, we had had good success with natokinase combined with LB core, which is the Stephen Herb Buhner Lyme protocol for combining five herbs.  And that seemed to be working pretty well for us.  But we had a lot of other things.  we were doing, tinctures and this and that. But Melody kept noticing that I wasn't tolerating it well.  And I was just stubbornly sticking with it longer than I probably should have given, you know, just pay attention to what your body's telling you.  And what happened was I ended up being concerned because I had a previous history of Crohn's disease that maybe this, uh, bleeding which I was happening internally could have been related to something that needed a recurrence of my Crohn's.  so better have a look with a colonoscopy.  having interviewed dr.  Jane Nielsen in the past he had expressed one of the news stories which he's flashed up to us before.  was that even properly sanitized whatever that means colonoscopes can pass infectious diseases from one patient to another one being C diff And C. diff is a particularly dangerous and can be fatal bacterial infection you can get in your intestines.  So I was concerned.  I consulted with him about it.  He said, yeah, you might want to be careful.  So I consulted with the GI about it and said, I don't know if I want to go through this colonoscopy, but we really wanted to find out the source of the internal bleeding, but we didn't want to risk that.  He said, oh, it's very low, very low risk.  So especially since it was nearing the end of the year and we were under the time pressure of our insurance deductible, which had been satisfied that year, would have been much, make the procedure much cheaper to do in December, much more expensive to do after that.  I thought, all right, we'll go ahead and do it.  We're going to, about to travel internationally.  I just want to get this thing done.  So went in and subjected to a colonoscopy and, uh, came through that pretty well.  Yeah, no, right, yeah.  No problem for the colonoscopy, and the results were all clear, looks good and clean.

This is the theme of stubborn Dunnigan versus wise Melody, I think.
Anyway, I'm just saying.
I can't deny it.
He really should have rested, and you didn't.

And if you think about the potential seriousness of you're going into a hospital or serious clinic environment, they're using a colonoscope, which they have used inside somebody else's body. it's quite healing and soothing to the gut actually very soothing to the gut And mallow, it's in the family of, like, marshmallow, and it's also called malva. yeah she said that's an interesting recipe.  she said take a green apple.
so it's the flesh not the peel.  You peel it.

What we are saying is that there are some alternatives you're probably not being told about, and there are some risks you're probably not being told about.  So help to find out about that.  For one thing, if your doctor is saying you need a routine screening just because it's been five years or just because you're over the age of 45 or 50 or something, that doesn't mean you need, if you're not sick and you're not suspected of being sick, it doesn't mean that the only way to check you out is with a colonoscopy.

Right.  There's two other options that we've heard of.  One is Cologuard.  And one is they call it capsule endoscopy.  It's a swallowing of a camera.  The other one, obviously, the Cologuard, you just send in a stool sample, and they can tell many things from that.
Whether you're at high risk for colon cancer.

You can't use that twice.  It just goes in and goes out, and you don't even aren't aware of it.  So those are two safer options.  But again, if you really feel you need a colonoscopy and they need to be sure because they need to take a sample, that is the only way to do it.
